title: Rinder: A Web-Based Social Connection Platform
author: CÃ©sar Perales, Isabella Romero, Gianpier Segovia

content.content: Rinder is a full-stack web application designed for social discovery and dating, architected using Python and the Flask framework. Developed as a collaborative academic project, the platform implements core functionalities essential to social networking, including user profiling, mutual-interest matching algorithms, real-time messaging, and content distribution systems.

The system was initially engineered as a monolithic architecture using Flask for both server-side logic and template rendering. To evolve the platform, we conducted an experimental migration to Vue.js to decouple the frontend. The current public demonstration utilizes a Next.js (React) fork integrated with simulated datasets for high-performance client-side rendering.

The backend manages complex relational data and implements a comprehensive RESTful API for CRUD operations:

- CREATE: User registration, post publication, asynchronous messaging, and preference signaling.
- READ: Dynamic profile retrieval, match visualization, messaging history, and social feeds.
- UPDATE: Profile management and real-time preference adjustments.
- DELETE: Account deactivation and content removal.

PostgreSQL serves as the primary relational database, ensuring data integrity across user entities, matches, and communication logs.
Matching Subsystem: A high-fidelity interface where users evaluate peer profiles. The system monitors reciprocal preference signals to trigger 'Match' events.
Communication Subsystem: A secure chat environment for matched users, featuring message persistence, historical retrieval, and notification triggers.

The application features a tiered service model with specific constraint management:

- Free: Standard access with interaction limits and advertisement integration.
- Premium: Enhanced daily interaction thresholds and an ad-free experience.
- VIP: Unlimited interactions, ad-free environment, and advanced analytics, such as profile visit tracking.

- Backend: Python, Flask, SQLAlchemy (ORM)
- Database: PostgreSQL (Port 5432)
- Primary Frontend: Jinja2 Templates
- Experimental Frontend: Vue.js
- Demonstration Layer: React/Next.js
- Authentication: Session-based security management via Flask

Rinder represents a fundamental milestone in full-stack engineering, demonstrating proficiency in relational database management, collaborative version control, and the implementation of secure authentication protocols within a distributed team environment.
